Literature Review: Eye care access and utilization are critical components of overall health and well-being, yet significant disparities persist in the United States. This literature review aims to synthesize current research on factors influencing eye care access and utilization, using the Healthy People 2030 framework as a guide to explore social determinants of health associated with various aspects of eye care.One of the primary factors contributing to disparities in eye care access is socioeconomic status. Numerous studies have demonstrated that individuals with lower income and education levels are less likely to receive regular eye examinations and necessary treatments. For instance, Zhang et al. (2012) found that adults with higher income and education were more likely to have had a recent eye examination, even after controlling for other factors such as age and health insurance status.Health insurance coverage plays a crucial role in eye care utilization. Uninsured individuals are significantly less likely to receive routine eye care and are at higher risk for undiagnosed eye conditions. Chou et al. (2014) reported that adults without health insurance were nearly three times more likely to have unmet eye care needs compared to those with insurance. Moreover, even among insured individuals, the type and extent of coverage can impact eye care utilization. Vision insurance, which is often separate from general health insurance, has been shown to increase the likelihood of receiving eye examinations and necessary treatments (Li et al., 2013).Racial and ethnic disparities in eye care access and utilization have been well-documented in the literature. African Americans and Hispanics, in particular, face significant barriers to eye care. A study by Elam et al. (2017) found that African Americans were less likely to receive dilated eye examinations and had higher rates of vision impairment compared to non-Hispanic whites. Similarly, Varma et al. (2016) reported that Hispanics had lower rates of eye care utilization and were more likely to have undiagnosed eye diseases such as diabetic retinopathy.Geographic location is another important factor influencing eye care access. Rural areas often face shortages of eye care professionals and facilities, leading to reduced access and utilization. Gibson et al. (2015) found that individuals living in rural areas were less likely to receive regular eye examinations and had higher rates of vision impairment compared to their urban counterparts. This disparity is particularly pronounced for specialized eye care services, such as retinal examinations for diabetic patients.Age-related disparities in eye care utilization have also been observed. While older adults are at higher risk for many eye conditions, they often face barriers to accessing care. Lam and Lee (2015) reported that older adults, particularly those with limited mobility or transportation issues, were less likely to receive regular eye examinations. Conversely, children and adolescents may also face barriers to eye care, with socioeconomic factors and parental awareness playing significant roles in determining access and utilization (Kemper et al., 2011).Cultural and linguistic factors can significantly impact eye care utilization among diverse populations. Language barriers, cultural beliefs about health and healthcare, and lack of culturally competent care can all contribute to disparities in eye care access. A study by Fang et al. (2016) found that limited English proficiency was associated with lower rates of eye care utilization among Asian Americans, highlighting the need for language-appropriate services and education.The advent of teleophthalmology has the potential to address some of the disparities in eye care access, particularly for rural and underserved populations. However, the implementation and utilization of teleophthalmology services are not uniform across different demographic groups. Woodward et al. (2017) reported that while teleophthalmology can improve access to care, barriers such as limited digital literacy and lack of internet access can create new disparities in eye care utilization.Patient-centered qualitative research has provided valuable insights into the reasons behind eye care disparities. Owsley et al. (2018) conducted focus groups with African American adults and identified several barriers to eye care utilization, including lack of knowledge about eye health, fear of diagnosis, and mistrust of the healthcare system. These findings underscore the importance of addressing not only structural barriers but also psychosocial factors that influence eye care-seeking behaviors.To address these disparities and improve eye care access and utilization, several recommendations have been proposed in the literature. These include expanding health insurance coverage for vision care, increasing the number of eye care professionals in underserved areas, implementing culturally competent eye health education programs, and leveraging technology to improve access to care. Additionally, addressing social determinants of health, such as poverty and education, is crucial for reducing eye care disparities in the long term.In conclusion, this review highlights the complex interplay of factors contributing to disparities in eye care access and utilization in the United States. By understanding these disparities and their underlying causes, policymakers, healthcare providers, and researchers can work towards developing targeted interventions to improve eye health equity and ensure that all individuals have access to necessary eye care services.
